label.en: By national standards, is the watershed considered
Indicate if the described watershed is representative of a larger watershed, river basin, or region.
If precise area is not known, indicate approximately.
Key reason(s) for selecting this watershed for assessment and documentation

helptext.en:
This detailed description should provide a concise but comprehensive picture of the watershed and its management to outsiders. Major differences of the three zones of the watershed should be highlighted. It should therefore address key questions such as:

  1. Where is the watershed located (natural and human environment)?
  2. What are the main problems/ challenges and what are the main objectives of the watershed management?
  3. What are the main Technologies applied (technical, social, and institutional)?
  4. Who are the main target groups/ beneficiaries?
  5. Who are the implementing partners and what is their role?
  6. What are the environmental, social, cultural, and economic impacts of watershed management?

The description should ideally be 2,500-3,000 characters in length; the absolute maximum is 3,500 characters. More detailed descriptions may be uploaded to the database as separate documents.

label.en: Describe major results illustrated by the map
Describe a scenario for improved watershed management based on different scenario runs in the offline app.
Are there conflicts between upstream and downstream land users?
Are there synergies between upstream and downstream land users?

helptext.en: E.g. down-stream hydro-power companies invest in SLM upstream

label.en: Are there dependencies between upstream and downstream users?

helptext.en: E.g. regulated water flow of rivers, groundwater recharge

Define the area of the watershed
Coordinates in latitude and longitude at the outlet and / or centre of the watershed area
Key reason(s) for selecting this watershed for assessment and documentation

helptext.en:
• Provide photos showing an overview and details of the three zones of the watershed
  • Provide at least two digital files (JPG, PNG, GIF), i.e. files from a digital camera, or scans from prints, negative films, or slide films.
  • Maximum file size: 3 MB.
  • Photos should be of high quality/ high resolution and not manipulated or distorted.
  • An explanation (description) is required for each photo submitted!

Example:

Sourakhak watershed, Afghanistan, used for fuel, fodder, grazing, and cash crops (photo: S. Bhuchar, Helvetas)

Structural measures (contour trenches, check dams, water harvesting structures) in combination with management (grazing and shrub-cutting management) and vegetative measures applied in Baqa Kushta watershed, Afghanistan (photo: S. Bhuchar, Helvetas)
Upload the map of the delineated major Land Use Types (LUTs), Land Use Sub-Types (LUSTs), and Land Management (LM) for each zone of the watershed (current situation) in one map.

label.en: Additional map(s) that support(s) characterization of the watershed

helptext.en: If available provide any other map(s) that support(s) characterization of the watershed (e.g. altitude, annual rainfall, slopes, soils etc.).

label.en: Are there dependencies between upstream and downstream land users?

Describe a scenario for improved watershed management
Strengths/ advantages/ opportunities of watershed management activities

Links to relevant information that is available online

helptext.en:
Definition of a watershed: A watershed is a topographically limited area from which all water is drained by acommon water course/ outlet. A watershed is also known as a catchment or basin. (NB: take care not to confusewith another use of the term in the US, where “watershed” can mean the actual divide between two catchmentsfrom where water is shed in opposite directions, rather than the area with a common water flow or drainagesystem).

A watershed captures precipitation, filters and stores water and determines its release (Schreier et al. 1997). Theland, vegetation, and water and resource users (farmers, herders, industries, urban people, livestock, wildlife, etc.)are its main constituents. The human and environmental components are closely connected and interdependent insuch a way that a change in one component impacts the integrity of the other.

Definition of watershed management: Watershed management is the integrated use of land, vegetation, andwater in a geographically discrete catchment or drainage area for the benefit of its residents, with the objective ofmaintaining the hydrological and other services that the watershed provides, and of reducing or avoiding negativedownstream or groundwater impacts (adapted from The World Bank, 2008). This implies also monitoring otherecological services such as soil productivity; biodiversity; the carbon cycle; climate change adaptation andmitigation; and sociocultural services such as aesthetics, recreation, tourism, heritage, etc.

Figure 1: Illustration of a watershed (source: https://dutchesswam.wordpress.com/)

label.en: Results of the watershed mapping and assessment

helptext.en: The results are based on the offline watershed assessment tool and uploaded to the online database.
